Literature Review: Viral membrane fusion represents a critical step in the life cycle of enveloped viruses, facilitating the release of viral genomes into host cells and initiating the replication process. This complex biological event is orchestrated by viral fusion proteins, which undergo significant conformational changes to merge the viral and host cell membranes. The study of these proteins not only sheds light on fundamental virological processes but also informs the development of antiviral therapies and vaccines. This literature review explores the mechanisms of viral membrane fusion, focusing on the classification of viral fusion proteins, their structural dynamics, and their interactions with lipid bilayers, as well as the implications for therapeutic interventions.Viral fusion proteins are categorized into three classes based on their structural and functional characteristics. Class I fusion proteins, exemplified by the influenza virus hemagglutinin (HA) and the HIV envelope glycoprotein (Env), are characterized by the presence of a central alpha-helical coiled-coil structure. These proteins undergo a dramatic conformational change from a prefusion to a postfusion state, a process that is often triggered by low pH or receptor binding (Harrison, 2015). Class II fusion proteins, found in flaviviruses and alphaviruses, adopt a different architecture, with beta-sheets dominating their structure. The transition to the postfusion state involves the rearrangement of these beta-sheets into a trimeric hairpin (Kielian & Rey, 2006). Class III fusion proteins, represented by the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) G protein, share features with both Class I and II proteins but are distinguished by their unique structural elements and fusion mechanisms (Roche et al., 2008).The fusion process is energetically demanding, requiring the overcoming of significant barriers to merge two distinct lipid bilayers. Viral fusion proteins facilitate this process through the insertion of fusion peptides or loops into the host membrane, followed by the formation of a hemifusion stalk and the eventual creation of a fusion pore (Chernomordik & Kozlov, 2008). The lipid composition of the viral and host membranes plays a crucial role in this process, influencing the efficiency and kinetics of fusion (Lorizate & Kräusslich, 2011).Understanding the structural intermediates between the pre- and postfusion states of viral fusion proteins has been a major focus of research. High-resolution structural studies have revealed the intricate details of these transitions, providing insights into the molecular mechanisms of membrane fusion (Harrison, 2015). The trimers-of-hairpins motif, a common feature in the postfusion state of many viral fusion proteins, represents a critical intermediate that brings the viral and host membranes into close proximity (Weissenhorn et al., 1999).The interplay between viral fusion proteins and lipid bilayers is complex and multifaceted. Fusion peptides and loops interact with the lipid bilayer in a manner that is influenced by the specific lipid composition, including the presence of cholesterol and sphingolipids (Lorizate & Kräusslich, 2011). These interactions are essential for the successful execution of membrane fusion and are targets for therapeutic intervention.Cellular factors that restrict viral fusion, known as fusion restriction factors, represent an important aspect of the host's antiviral defense mechanisms. These factors can inhibit the fusion process at various stages, providing a potential avenue for the development of novel antiviral therapies (Brass et al., 2009). Additionally, neutralizing antibodies that target viral fusion proteins are a critical component of the immune response and are the basis for many successful vaccines (Burton & Hangartner, 2016).In conclusion, the study of viral membrane fusion proteins offers valuable insights into the fundamental processes of viral entry and pathogenesis. The classification of these proteins into distinct classes, the elucidation of their structural dynamics, and the understanding of their interactions with lipid bilayers have advanced our knowledge of virology and informed the development of therapeutic strategies. Continued research in this field is essential for addressing the challenges posed by emerging and re-emerging viral pathogens.
